_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Milliken Chemical, a Division of Milliken & Company, owns and operates the Allen Plant.  The Allen Plant is a specialty chemical batch operation located in Blacksburg, SC, which is approximately 5 miles northeast of Gaffney, SC.



The first priority of the Allen Plant is the health and safety of its associates and the surrounding community.  OSHA recognized the Allen Plant as a Star site in 1997 and has re-certified this classification since then in 2006, 2007, 2010 and 2013.  Of equal importance is protection of the environment.  To this end significant resources are committed to ensuring complete compliance with all regulations and that the plant is operated in a manner that protects the quality of our environment.



The U.S. EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) regulates Phosphorous Oxychloride when it is stored in quantities in excess of 5,000 pounds in a single location.  Allen is subject to these regulations because it stores this chemical above the 5,000 pound threshold.  Allen currently receives and stores Phosphorous Oxychloride in drums.  Storing it in quantities above 5,000 pounds will allow the plant to receive full shipments rather than smaller, partial shipments.



Allen uses Phosphorous Oxychloride as a building block chemical in the manufacture of colorants to be used in plastics and urethane foams.



The Allen plant is a program 3 facility due to the fact that the worst-case scenario modeling for Phosphorous Oxychloride predicts the potential for off-site consequences.  Program 3 requires both a worst case and alternative case modeling analysis to be performed.



The U.S. EPA explicitly specifies the conditions of the worst case scenario release.  According to the General Guidance for Risk Management Programs (EPA 550-B-98-003) page 4-4, the chances of a worst case release occurring are very low.  The assumptions required for the worst case release are very conservative, including complete failure of all safety systems and worst case weather condi

tions for air dispersion: consequently, the results are very conservative.



The endpoints, which are specified for each toxic substance, are intended to protect the general public.  These endpoints are concentrations below which it is believed that nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to one hour without serious health effects.  The distance to the end point estimated under the worst case scenario should not be considered a zone in which the public would likely be in danger, but rather it is intended to provide an estimate of the maximum possible area that might be affected in the unlikely event of catastrophic conditions.  The EPA intended these distances to form the basis for discussion among the regulated community, emergency responders and the general public rather than the basis for any specific actions.



The worst case release scenario for the Allen Plant is a release of the contents from a 55-gallon drum of Phosphorous Oxychloride at the loading dock.  The assumption is that the entire contents of a drum would be released instantaneously.  There are residences and commercial areas within this radius.  As noted earlier in the quote from the U.S. EPA, the worst case scenario represents the maximum possible area that might be affected in the unlikely event of catastrophic conditions.



The alternative case scenario for Phosphorous Oxychloride is a 55-gallon drum rupture at the loading dock.  This scenario assumes typical meteorological conditions rather than worst-case conditions as used in the worst case release scenario.  Again, there are residences and commercial areas within this radius, though it is a smaller radius than the worst case scenario.  As noted earlier in the quote from the U.S. EPA, the worst case scenario represents the maximum possible area that might be affected in the unlikely event of catastrophic conditions.



The Allen Plant is committed to the education and training of all associates in the area of safety and emergency re

sponse.  For this reason, plant associates are ready to respond in the event of an emergency.  Plant associates are trained to respond to both fire and hazardous material emergencies.  In addition, the plant has worked closely with the Blacksburg Fire Department to ensure that they are prepared to respond in the event of an emergency.



While the possibility of an accident at the Allen Plant exists, the potential is low and Milliken Chemical takes preventative actions to minimize the possibility of an accident occurring.
